Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Score-Based Observation Versus Imaging in Early Equivocal Appendicitis

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to imaging or observation groups using computer-based block randomisation.

Participants.evidence: Adults with suspected appendicitis, symptoms for less than 24 hours, and an Adult Appendicitis Score (AAS) of 11â€“15 were eligible.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to imaging or observation groups.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate whether early imaging leads to more diagnoses of acute appendicitis compared to initial observation and to assess the safety and feasibility of score-based observation in patients with equivocal appendicitis signs.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the number of patients requiring treatment for acute appendicitis within 30 days.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Participants were randomised 1:1 to imaging or observation groups using computer-based block randomisation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From May 2016 to March 2020, 185 patients were randomised: 93 to imaging and 92 to observation.

Number_Analysed.evidence: After exclusions, 93 and 88 patients were analysed, respectively.

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the imaging group, 72% required treatment for appendicitis compared to 57% in the observation group (odds ratio 0.51, 95% CI 0.27 to 0.95; p = 0.032).
